column4: please, don't discourge people from trying things. Just because you may have had a bad experience dual booting win and linux, doesn't mean it will be a problem for others.
everyone has different hardware and does things a bit different if they "know what they are doing". remember, alot of folks that come here are new to ubuntu
i agree with that everyone that comes here is new to ubuntu  but what works works and whatdoes not  don't \
so if it doesn't work for you it doesn't work for anyone?
i  work on computers everyday and the rate of success for dual boot is about 19 percent

I understand as I do to. but, you had an issue and I don't have that issue. I have 150 engineers dual booting centos, ubuntu, and some of our custom linux distros all without issue. so again, for 1 to say it doesn't work because they had an issue and it won't work for others just doesn't make any sense to me.
i  agree some what but i would rather tell someone no instead of yes and have them lose there os and files
agreed, I wouldn't want someone to lose anything. and not for dual booting. I would say run a local vm instead.
yep vm or run live cd
I did it from 9:10 to 10.04 64bit, and it all went just fine (for me that is). but I agreed, a clean install is much easier in the long run.
yes some go ok but itis so much easier to just backup and do a fresh yes
yea new installs are much nicer to support than upgrades with system settings and prefs setup by and end user. that's a headache.
its a continuance thing probally before this line is over there will be one  > i upgradedfrom 9.10 to 10.04 and now i can not boot watch
